S3.T2.table:
Method MNIST Sampled-FEMNIST VSN HAR
Global 0.9678±plus-or-minus\pm0.0007 0.8326±plus-or-minus\pm0.008 0.926±plus-or-minus\pm0.004 0.797±plus-or-minus\pm0.006
Local 0.9511±plus-or-minus\pm0.0020 0.8299±plus-or-minus\pm0.005 0.960±plus-or-minus\pm0.003 0.940±plus-or-minus\pm0.001
FedAvg 0.9675±plus-or-minus\pm0.0004 0.8319±plus-or-minus\pm0.003 0.916±plus-or-minus\pm0.007 0.944±plus-or-minus\pm0.004
Virtual(CE) 0.9666±plus-or-minus\pm0.0017 0.8147±plus-or-minus\pm0.01 0.9340±plus-or-minus\pm0.002 0.9680±plus-or-minus\pm0.001

references: We used the balanced version of the datasets to get a baseline of the performance. In Table 2, we see that VIRTUAL with FFL does consistently better than the CE version. Here we measure the average accuracy over all classes on the test set and report the mean and standard deviations over the runs.

Loss function MNIST FEMNIST VSN HAR
Cross-entropy 0.6660±plus-or-minus\pm0.0015 0.6750±plus-or-minus\pm0.01 0.7981±plus-or-minus\pm0.002 0.8205±plus-or-minus\pm0.001

In Table 3, we observe the performance of FFL to classify hard samples (pt≪much-less-thansubscript𝑝𝑡absentp_{t}\ll 0.5) under single class and multi-class imbalance when compared with the cross-entropy.

S4.T4.table:
Loss Clients (ratio) Balanced MNIST Unbalanced MNIST Balanced FEMNIST Unbalanced FEMNIST
Cross-entropy 0.05 0.9507±plus-or-minus\pm0.0010 0.5574±plus-or-minus\pm0.0015 0.7614±plus-or-minus\pm0.015 0.5159±plus-or-minus\pm0.010
Fed-Focal 0.05 0.9590±plus-or-minus\pm0.0009 0.5635±plus-or-minus\pm0.0012 0.7814±plus-or-minus\pm0.015 0.5448±plus-or-minus\pm0.012
Cross-entropy 0.10 0.9687±plus-or-minus\pm0.0011 0.6660±plus-or-minus\pm0.0014 0.8147±plus-or-minus\pm0.010 0.6750±plus-or-minus\pm0.010

references: This study focused on how changing the number of clients to sample each round impacted the performance. We can see that in Table 4, the performance of both methods decreases at the sampling ratio of 0.05 or 0.15 clients, and the best results are obtained with a ratio of 0.10 clients.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Test Accuracy on Unbalanced MNIST at ψ=0.0𝜓0.0\psi=0.0 and α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0
S4.T5.table:
γ𝛾\gamma Accuracy
1.0 0.7486±plus-or-minus\pm0.0001
2.0 0.7840±plus-or-minus\pm0.0015
3.0 0.6786±plus-or-minus\pm0.0040
4.0 0.6736±plus-or-minus\pm0.0043
5.0 0.6220±plus-or-minus\pm0.0052
references: We study the variation of test accuracy with the tuning parameter γ𝛾\gamma of Fed Focal Loss. We can observe in Table 5 that smaller values of γ𝛾\gamma are suitable while larger values of γ𝛾\gamma lead to worse performance. γ𝛾\gamma = 1.0 and 2.0 deliver very good test set accuracies as compared to γ𝛾\gamma = 3.0, 4.0 and 5.0.

S4.T6.caption: Table 6: Test Accuracy on Unbalanced MNIST at γ=2.0𝛾2.0\gamma=2.0 and α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0
S4.T6.table:
ψ𝜓\psi Accuracy
0.0 0.7486±plus-or-minus\pm0.0001
0.2 0.7497±plus-or-minus\pm0.0001
0.6 0.7504±plus-or-minus\pm0.0002
0.8 0.7591±plus-or-minus\pm0.0010
1.0 0.7473±plus-or-minus\pm0.0030
references: We also study the variation of test accuracy with the tuning parameter ψ𝜓\psi of Fed Focal Loss. ψ𝜓\psi = 0.0 is when no particular focus is given to the client, while ψ𝜓\psi = 1.0 is when we focus only on all clients that have improved their performance in the previous round. In Table 6, we can observe that ψ𝜓\psi = 0.6 and 0.8 shows a significant improvement in the performance. Although we cannot generalize a specific tuned value as it strongly depends on the distribution of validation dataset, we found the best performance with ψ𝜓\psi = 0.8 and 0.6.
